title: Vignette for easypar
text: Consider dummy function f sleeps random time print output. f runs Input(s). want run f 4 inputs (random univariate numbers). store list position full set parameters want pass calls f (list lists), named according actual parameter names. easypar provides single function takes input f, list inputs execution parameters type execution requested. simplest call runs f parallel, without seeing output just receiving return values list follows can control amount (0 1) cores use maximum (checked via doPar). combinations also possible. make thread dump shared rds file result, implementing cache usefull one want real-time analyze output results (another process). get outputs screen (asynchronous per thread) outfile sequentially every tasks -loop fashion

title: Vignette for easypar
text: can disable parallel executions easily. global option force execution go serial, whatever source code default behaviour (parallel = TRUE work). f plugged tool called default parallel = TRUE, set global option easypar.parallel, easypar run f sequentially.
code: easypar::run(FUN = f, PARAMS = inputs) options(easypar.parallel = FALSE) easypar::run(FUN = f, PARAMS = inputs, parallel = TRUE) ## [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:36 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE ## [1] "Before sleep 0.177086027339101  - siesta for  1.66399476630613" ## [1] "After sleep 0.177086027339101" ## [1] "Before sleep 0.508358567021787  - siesta for  1.45875586010516" ## [1] "After sleep 0.508358567021787" ## [1] "Before sleep 0.732572568347678  - siesta for  1.95741358958185" ## [1] "After sleep 0.732572568347678" ## [1] "Before sleep 0.988466809038073  - siesta for  1.30386052560061" ## [1] "After sleep 0.988466809038073" ## $`1` ## [1] 0.177086 ##  ## $`2` ## [1] 0.5083586 ##  ## $`3` ## [1] 0.7325726 ##  ## $`4` ## [1] 0.9884668

title: Vignette for easypar
code: # Hopefully r will crash at least once but not all calls f = function(x)  {   if(runif(1) > .5) stop("Boom!!")      "Ok" }  # Restore parallel and run options(easypar.parallel = TRUE) runs = easypar::run(FUN = f, PARAMS = inputs, parallel = TRUE, outfile = NULL) ## [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:42 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : TRUE ## [easypar] 3/4 computations returned errors and will be removed. # inspect and filter function numErrors(runs) ## [1] 0 runs ## $`4` ## [1] "Ok" filterErrors(runs) ## $`4` ## [1] "Ok"

title: LSF array jobs with easypar
text: function FUN (e.g.,: FUN = ls) can run stand-alone R application, parameters manages explicitly dependencies. Note: FUN run indipendent process. dataframe PARAMS every row input FUN. column order must match FUN arguments. Conceptually, set data apply(FUN, MARGIN = 1) row. input column names without dots spaces; match arguments FUN. , instance, input 2-columns work FUN 2 parameters.

title: LSF array jobs with easypar
text: run_lsf generates 3 files: R script wrapping definition FUN, extra code call FUN using parameters command line. function script called fake name; csv file containing input PARAMS, without header (column names), row names. LSF array job submission script N jobs N rows PARAMS. submitting job, test computation explained .

title: LSF array jobs with easypar
text: Cluster-specific BSUB instructions can specified, well dependencies modules available cluster. Function run_lsf allows : specify list modules added dependencies LSF submission script. instance, modules = 'R/3.5.0' generate dependecy specific R version (3.5.0). customize BSUB parameters generated script. package comes default BSUB configuration, updated according cluster setup. classical BSUB parameters: -J, job ID; -P, project ID; -q, queue ID; -n -R, resources allocate; -W wall time jobs; -o -e, outputs error filenames. Notice default job array ID filename, one log per job. required modify default values -P -q, project queue ID, according LSF configuration. Otherwise, submission script generate error becaue default values mean anything. Modifications done default list parameters; BSUB flags can used well. checkings correctness done easypar. BSUB customized, can either: generate submission scripts, submit job manually generate submission scripts submit jobs system call. default (run = FALSE) run_lsf function outputs shell command used submit jobs, leaves user submit job. experienced command line issues calling modules system call.
code: library(easypar) ## Warning: replacing previous import 'cli::num_ansi_colors' by ## 'crayon::num_ansi_colors' when loading 'easypar' # Default parameters in the package default_BSUB_config() ## $`-J` ## [1] "EASYPAR_Runner" ##  ## $`-P` ## [1] "dummy_project" ##  ## $`-q` ## [1] "short" ##  ## $`-n` ## [1] 1 ##  ## $`-R` ## [1] "\"span[hosts=1]\"" ##  ## $`-W` ## [1] "4:00" ##  ## $`-o` ## [1] "log/output.%J.%I" ##  ## $`-e` ## [1] "log/errors.%J.%I" custom_BSUB = default_BSUB_config()  # More informative job ID custom_BSUB$`-J` = "bwa_aligner"  # A token for a project allowed to run on the cluster custom_BSUB$`-P` = "DKSMWOP331"  # A queue name that is valid on the cluster custom_BSUB$`-q` = "bioinformatics"  print(custom_BSUB) ## $`-J` ## [1] "bwa_aligner" ##  ## $`-P` ## [1] "DKSMWOP331" ##  ## $`-q` ## [1] "bioinformatics" ##  ## $`-n` ## [1] 1 ##  ## $`-R` ## [1] "\"span[hosts=1]\"" ##  ## $`-W` ## [1] "4:00" ##  ## $`-o` ## [1] "log/output.%J.%I" ##  ## $`-e` ## [1] "log/errors.%J.%I" # Shorter version custom_BSUB = default_BSUB_config(J = 'bwa_aligner', P = 'DKSMWOP331', q = 'bioinformatics')  print(custom_BSUB) ## $`-J` ## [1] "bwa_aligner" ##  ## $`-P` ## [1] "DKSMWOP331" ##  ## $`-q` ## [1] "bioinformatics" ##  ## $`-n` ## [1] 1 ##  ## $`-R` ## [1] "\"span[hosts=1]\"" ##  ## $`-W` ## [1] "4:00" ##  ## $`-o` ## [1] "log/output.%J.%I" ##  ## $`-e` ## [1] "log/errors.%J.%I"

title: LSF array jobs with easypar
text: example computation follows.
code: # A simple function that prints some outputs FUN = function(x, y){    print(x, y)  }  # input for 25 array jobs PARAMS = data.frame(   x = runif(25),    y = runif(25)   )  # generates the input files, adding some module dependencies run_lsf(FUN,          PARAMS,          BSUB_config = custom_BSUB,         modules = 'R/3.5.0'         ) ## ── easypar: LSF array jobs generator ─────────────────────────────────────────── ## → Destination folder: . ## Creating folder for output and error logs:  log ## ✔ LSF submission script: #!/bin/bash ##  ## #BSUB -J bwa_aligner[1-25] ## #BSUB -P DKSMWOP331 ## #BSUB -q bioinformatics ## #BSUB -n 1 ## #BSUB -R "span[hosts=1]" ## #BSUB -W 4:00 ## #BSUB -o log/output.%J.%I ## #BSUB -e log/errors.%J.%I ##  ## # =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-==-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= ## # Automatic LSF script generated via easypar ## # 2022-05-11 16:27:47 ## # =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-==-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= ##  ## # Required modules ## module load R/3.5.0  ##  ##  ## # Input file and R script ## file_input=EASYPAR_LSF_input_jobarray.csv ## R_script=EASYPAR_LSF_Run.R ## line=$LSB_JOBINDEX ##  ## # Data loading ## x=$( awk -v line=$line 'BEGIN {FS="\t"}; FNR==line {print $1}' $file_input) ## y=$( awk -v line=$line 'BEGIN {FS="\t"}; FNR==line {print $2}' $file_input) ##  ## # Job run ## Rscript $R_script $x $y (R runner: EASYPAR_LSF_Run.R) ## ✔  Input file (head of): EASYPAR_LSF_input_jobarray.csv ## ## ── Scripts generated ── ## ##  ## Job submission: bsub < EASYPAR_LSF_submission.sh ##    Job testing: Rscript EASYPAR_LSF_Run.R 0.63901305035688 0.46978895040229

title: LSF array jobs with easypar
text: try run automatically, command bsub < EASYPAR_LSF_submission.sh submit jobs cluster.

title: Easy parallaleization of R functions.
text: easypar makes easy implement parallel computations R. youo function carries desired computation, easypar take care burden turning function runnable parallel piece R code. package offers two possible solutions parallelisation. can generate parallel function call exploiting foreach doParallel paradigms parallel computing, can generate ready--use array job popular LSF (Platform Load Sharing Facility) Slurm workload manages distributed high performance computing. easypar, speeding R computations parallelism trivial task.

title: Easy parallaleization of R functions.
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("caravagnalab/easypar")

code: default_BSUB_config(   J = "EASYPAR_Runner",   P = "dummy_project",   q = "short",   n = 1,   R = "\"span[hosts=1]\"",   W = "4:00",   o = "log/output.%J.%I",   e = "log/errors.%J.%I" )

text: named list BSUB settings.

code: custom_BSUB = default_BSUB_config(W = '12:00') custom_BSUB$`-J` = "Myjob" custom_BSUB$`-P` = "my_project" custom_BSUB$`-q` = "my_queue"

what: Filter out the tasks with errors. — filterErrors
title: Filter out the tasks with errors. — filterErrors
text: Filter tasks errors.

title: Filter out the tasks with errors. — filterErrors
code: filterErrors(R)

title: Filter out the tasks with errors. — filterErrors
text: R list outputs run

title: Filter out the tasks with errors. — filterErrors
text: list tasks without errors

title: Filter out the tasks with errors. — filterErrors
code: # Errors can be intercepted. Consider a function # that can generate some error. The run will not plot and # the computation will run anyway.   results = run(   FUN = function(x) {     if(runif(1) > .5) stop("Some error")     x   },   PARAMS = lapply(1:5, list),   silent = TRUE ) #> [easypar] 2/5 computations returned errors and will be removed.  # Getter that can filter them out  filterErrors(results) #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>

what: Inspects the logs of an LSF array job. — lsf_logs_inspector
title: Inspects the logs of an LSF array job. — lsf_logs_inspector
text: array job generated `easypar`'s function run_lsf, can use function inspect logs. functions takes process identifier (PID), scans logs folder selecting belonging array jobs run PID. every output file, standard LSF closing text "Successfully completed." searched . found relative error file scanned find error message (grepping "Error" term file), displayed screen. Log files jobs run succesfully compressed zip file stored log folders, error logs retained. list input(s) associated error logs also print screen, summary table retuned.

title: Inspects the logs of an LSF array job. — lsf_logs_inspector
code: lsf_logs_inspector(PID, errors_folder, input_file, delete_files = TRUE)

title: Inspects the logs of an LSF array job. — lsf_logs_inspector
text: PID Process identier, appear names logfiles. errors_folder folder logs inspect. input_file input file associated job, NULL inputs runs error shown screen.

title: Inspects the logs of an LSF array job. — lsf_logs_inspector
text: tibble name jobs analysed, file references output status.

title: Inspects the logs of an LSF array job. — lsf_logs_inspector
code: # very dummy example function FUN = function(x, y){ print(x, y) }  # input for 25 array jobs PARAMS = data.frame(x = runif(25), y = runif(25))  if (FALSE) { # not run  run_lsf(FUN, PARAMS)  # Once logs are produced... we can inspect them   # inspect using default params (as in job submission) lsf_logs_inspector(PID = 1234, errors_folder = 'log', input_file = 'EASYPAR_LSF_input_jobarray.csv') }

title: Return the number of tasks with errors — numErrors
code: numErrors(R)

title: Return the number of tasks with errors — numErrors
text: R list outputs run

title: Return the number of tasks with errors — numErrors
text: number tasks errors

title: Return the number of tasks with errors — numErrors
code: # Errors can be intercepted. Consider a function # that can generate some error. The run will not plot and # the computation will run anyway.  options(easypar.parallel = FALSE)  results = run(   FUN = function(x) {     if(runif(1) > .5) stop("Some error")     x   },   PARAMS = lapply(1:5, list),   silent = TRUE ) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> [easypar] 1/5 computations returned errors and will be removed.  # Getters that can return the number of errors  numErrors(results) #> [1] 0

what: Run a function with easypar — run
title: Run a function with easypar — run
text: Run task list inputs, making easy parallelize run sequential session. glonal option easypar.parallel set, parameter parallel overwritten. allows easily switch debug non-debug execution modes task.

title: Run a function with easypar — run
code: run(   FUN,   PARAMS,   packages = NULL,   export = NULL,   cores.ratio = 0.8,   parallel = TRUE,   silent = TRUE,   outfile = "",   cache = NULL,   progress_bar = TRUE,   filter_errors = TRUE )

title: Run a function with easypar — run
text: FUN R function run PARAMS List parameters, entry needs match arguments FUN packages Packages load parallel thread export Variables export parallel thread cores.ratio Ratio available cores used parallel run, default 80%. parallel Boolean value, TRUE parallel execution, FALSE standard loop. silent Silent output easypar. outfile Output file parallel thread, default "" console, NA default. cache Cache used computation dump results template RDS file. progress_bar Boolean value, default TRUE. Print progress_bar execution. filter_errors `TRUE`, errors intercepted filtered returning results.

title: Run a function with easypar — run
code: # A very simple function dummy_fun = function(x) {x}  # Parameters dummy_params = lapply(1:5, list)  # Default run: parallel, silent, output to screen run(dummy_fun, dummy_params) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>   # Run serially with progress_bar run(dummy_fun, dummy_params, parallel = FALSE) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [FALSE] with global option : FALSE #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>  # Run serially without progress_bar run(dummy_fun, dummy_params, parallel = FALSE, progress_bar = FALSE) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [FALSE] with global option : FALSE #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>   # Run parallel, not silent, caching the results run(dummy_fun, dummy_params, silent = FALSE, cache = "MyCache.rds") #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Computing 5 tasks. #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Caching outputs to : /tmp/Rtmp7pDoTM/file30a45b2015b/reference/MyCache.rds #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Running sequentially. #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>  file.remove("MyCache.rds") #> [1] TRUE  # Overwriting default setting with global options options(easypar.parallel = FALSE) run(dummy_fun, dummy_params) # Will run sequentially #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>   options(easypar.progress_bar = FALSE) # Will hide the progress bar run(dummy_fun, dummy_params) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding progress bar setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`2` #> [1] 2 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`4` #> [1] 4 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>   # Errors can be intercepted. Consider a function # that can generate some error. The run will not plot and # the computation will run anyway.  options(easypar.parallel = TRUE)  results = run(   FUN = function(x) {     if(runif(1) > .5) stop("Some error")     x   },   PARAMS = dummy_params,   silent = TRUE,   filter_errors = FALSE ) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : TRUE #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:10 - Overriding progress bar setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE  # Getters that can return the number of errors # and filter them out  numErrors(results) #> [1] 2  filterErrors(results) #> $`1` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $`3` #> [1] 3 #>  #> $`5` #> [1] 5 #>   #' Can do this automatically with filter_errors = TRUE results = run(   FUN = function(x) {     if(runif(1) > .5) stop("Some error")     x   },   PARAMS = dummy_params,   silent = TRUE,   filter_errors = TRUE ) #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:11 - Overriding parallel execution setup [TRUE] with global option : TRUE #> [easypar] 2022-05-11 16:27:11 - Overriding progress bar setup [TRUE] with global option : FALSE #> [easypar] 4/5 computations returned errors and will be removed.

what: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
title: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
text: function submits array jobs LDF clusters. input function can carry full computation , plus data.frame row represents inputs function expecting. input data.frame dumped file, input function wrapped inside automatically generated R script gathers inputs command line. SLURM submission script generated bash shell. function can also run SLURM command `sbatch` submit job, just generate required  files prompt user submit job via shell. SLURM parameters can provided list parameters, similarly modules custom filenames generated scripts.

title: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
code: run_SLURM(   FUN,   PARAMS,   SBATCH_config = default_SBATCH_config(),   modules = c("R/4.1.0"),   extra_commands = NULL,   input_file = "EASYPAR_SLURM_input_jobarray.csv",   R_script = "EASYPAR_SLURM_Run.R",   Submission_script = "EASYPAR_SLURM_submission.sh",   output_folder = ".",   per_task = 1,   N_simultaneous_jobs = NULL,   run = FALSE )

title: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
text: FUN function takes arguments input, performs computation. function runnable standalone R script. PARAMS data.frame row represents inputs FUN. array job many rows PARAMS generated. SBATCH_config list SBATCH commands SLURM cluster provided. default input obtained call default_SBATCH_config(). queue project ID always provided cluster-specific.  Otherwise, default values prompt errors submitting job. modules list modules added dependencies SLURM submission script. instance modules = 'R/3.5.0' generate dependecy specific R version "module load R/3.5.0". extra_commands Extra set commands executed submission script right modules declaration. input_file name data.frame input file generated PARAMS. file contains header, row names. R_script name R script file contains definition FUN, autogenerated R code call function input parameters command line. Function FUN given fake name script. Submission_script name SLURM script file contains  submission routines. output_folder output thsi function sent folder. run `TRUE`, function attempt invoking `SBATCH` submit array jobs. Otherwise print screen instructions run job manually console.

title: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
text: Nothing, funciton just generates required inputs submit array job via SLURM clusters. required, also attempts submitting jobs.

title: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
text: queue project ID `SBATCH_config`   always provided cluster-specific. Default values prompt errors submitting job. Besides, found automatic job submission can sometimes generate `command found` types errors. Manual  submission seems generally safest option submit SLURM jobs.

title: Submit array jobs to SLURM clusters. — run_SLURM
code: # very dummy example function FUN = function(x, y){ print(x, y) }  # input for 25 array jobs PARAMS = data.frame(x = runif(25), y = runif(25))  if (FALSE) { # call - not run since it's cluster-specific run_SLURM(FUN, PARAMS) }

what: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
title: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
text: function submits array jobs LSF clusters. input function can carry full computation , plus data.frame row represents inputs function expecting. input data.frame dumped file, input function wrapped inside automatically generated R script gathers inputs command line. LSF submission script generated bash shell. function can also run LSF command `bsub` submit job, just generate required  files prompt user submit job via shell. LSF parameters can provided list parameters, similarly modules custom filenames generated scripts.

title: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
code: run_lsf(   FUN,   PARAMS,   BSUB_config = default_BSUB_config(),   modules = c("R/3.5.0"),   extra_commands = NULL,   input_file = "EASYPAR_LSF_input_jobarray.csv",   R_script = "EASYPAR_LSF_Run.R",   Submission_script = "EASYPAR_LSF_submission.sh",   output_folder = ".",   run = FALSE )

title: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
text: FUN function takes arguments input, performs computation. function runnable standalone R script. PARAMS data.frame row represents inputs FUN. array job many rows PARAMS generated. BSUB_config list BSUB commands LSF cluster provided. default input obtained call default_BSUB_config(). queue project ID always provided cluster-specific.  Otherwise, default values prompt errors submitting job. modules list modules added dependencies LSF submission script. instance modules = 'R/3.5.0' generate dependecy specific R version "module load R/3.5.0". extra_commands Extra set commands executed submission script right modules declaration. input_file name data.frame input file generated PARAMS. file contains header, row names. R_script name R script file contains definition FUN, autogenerated R code call function input parameters command line. Function FUN given fake name script. Submission_script name LSF script file contains  submission routines. output_folder output thsi function sent folder. run `TRUE`, function attempt invoking `bsub` submit array jobs. Otherwise print screen instructions run job manually console.

title: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
text: Nothing, funciton just generates required inputs submit array job via LSF clusters. required, also attempts submitting jobs.

title: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
text: queue project ID `BSUB_config`   always provided cluster-specific. Default values prompt errors submitting job. Besides, found automatic job submission can sometimes generate `command found` types errors. Manual  submission seems generally safest option submit LSF jobs.

title: Submit array jobs to LSF clusters. — run_lsf
code: # very dummy example function FUN = function(x, y){ print(x, y) }  # input for 25 array jobs PARAMS = data.frame(x = runif(25), y = runif(25))  if (FALSE) { # call - not run since it's cluster-specific run_lsf(FUN, PARAMS) }
